video.title: Unreal Engine Tutorial - Create a 2D Snake Game [Code + Assets]
video.description:
Learn how to create a 2D Snake Game with Unreal Engine in this full tutorial. In this beginner's course, you will how to create a game with Unreal Engine and Blueprints.

💻 Project assets: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1sd9LkLQ4z6Q0CaoBsL94yFo_zW0E0fWa/view?usp=sharing
💻 Completed project: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1CcYTmVbMl4Feoyt8QNknCajJQfEYYSfo/view?usp=sharing

🎥 Course from Awesome Tuts. Check out their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/awesometuts

🔗 Learn more about game development here: https://www.awesometuts.com/ultimate-game-dev-academy?utm_medium=youtube&utm_source=freecodecamp

topLevelComment.text: Has anyone found a solution to completely rid the input delay?

replies.author: Jordan H
replies.text: Hi! I've figured this one out. In the main game blueprint, after Event Tick, disconnect the collapsed graph named "Wait" and move it to just after 'Check inputs' and before 'Move snake'. Connect the nodes again. Next, open the collapsed graph 'Spawn new snake part' and disconnect the return value after 'SpawnActorLocation'. Drag off from the return value and type 'Vector - int'. set the integer value to '1' and connect the return value to the Spawn location on 'Spawn new snake part' blueprint. This solves the input delay bug. Hope this helps!

topLevelComment.author: Liang Men
topLevelComment.text: The blackish dot in the centre is the "defaultPawn", which you can see it in the World Outliner in play mode. It is automatically added into the scene because this Snake Game does not use any pawns. An easy way to solve this  is to add a pawn, double click the pawn, set "auto possess player" to player 0, and then add it to the scene.

topLevelComment.author: Ben Brooker
topLevelComment.text:
Anyone have any advice for a university student (Economics - can't switch to CompSci) wanting an internship as a back-end software engineer?
Have 2 years left at uni and i've been teaching myself code in my spare time. I can currently work with Java, Python, R, SQL and do not have any relevent work experience. Should I freelance, learn more languages, join hackathons etc.. ? Cheers!

replies.author: Jayadeep Mir
replies.text:
I'm no recruiter but I'd say you should do projects you can showcase. If you're into game development, you could put together a few simple, working games to showcase your skills. Projects show how well you can apply your skills. Hackathons and challenges on sites like Hackerrank are good but you may not want to showcase them if you're not regular with them.
I would definitely say that you get certified, because most of the tech jobs require a degree in the field. They generally mention a degree "in Computer Science or a related field," but I'm not sure if economics will count (Mathematics usually does, but even then, you'll need more than just your degree to stand out).

topLevelComment.author: anonymous user
topLevelComment.text: Which game engine do you suggest for a beginner?

replies.author: Jayadeep Mir
replies.text:
Depends on what "beginner" means. You should start with learning basic programming concepts, specifically object-oriented programming (at least the basics, even if coding is not your main thing and you're more into the art side of things), before moving to any game engine, because if you're not clear on OOP concepts, you may not understand a lot of the stuff that's going on with "base classes" and "public/exposed variables" or "data members" or even why you need an interface like UE4's Blueprint communication to communicate between two classes.
As for game engines, the Godot engine is beginner-friendly. Unity and Unreal may be a bit overwhelming if you've never used 3D software before, but if you want to develop 3D games, they're both very popular engines. If you're interested professionally, having a project or two made using Unity or Unreal would definitely work in your favor.
